'''Phelim P. Boyle''' (born 1941), is an Irish economist and [[distinguished professor]] and [[actuary]], and a pioneer of [[quantitative finance]]. He is best known for initiating the use of [[Monte Carlo method]]s in [[option (finance)|option pricing]].<ref>[http://www.soa.org/library/newsletters/the-actuary-magazine/2006/april/act-interview-boyle.aspx An Interview with Dr. Phelim Boyle, IAFE/SunGard Financial Engineer of the Year] at ''soa.org''. Accessed September 11, 2013.</ref>

== Biography ==
Born on a farm in [[Lavey, County Londonderry|Lavey]], [[County Londonderry]], [[Northern Ireland]], Phelim Boyle attended Dreenan School, [[Garron Tower]] and [[Queen's University Belfast]] ([[B.Sc.]]) He earned his [[M.Sc.]], and [[PhD]] in [[applied mathematics]], specialising in [[physics]], from [[Trinity College, Dublin]].<ref>[http://www.wlu.ca/documents/50852/Phelim_Boyle_CV.pdf Curriculum Vitae]</ref>

He is a professor of [[finance]] in the [[Laurier School of Business & Economics]] at [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] in [[Canada]].<ref>[https://www.wlu.ca/homepage.php?grp_id=1855&ct_id=1607&f_id=31 WLU Faculty Page]</ref> Until June 2006 he held the J Page R Wadsworth Chair at the [[University of Waterloo]].  Additional to his contributions to quantitative finance, he has published papers on actuarial science and [[demography]]. Together with his son, [[Feidhlim Boyle]], he authored the highly readable ''Derivatives: the Tools that Changed Finance''. He continues to contribute in the area of [[quantitative finance]].

He has been awarded the Centennial Gold Medal of the [[International Actuarial Association]] and was the recipient of the [[International Association of Financial Engineers|IAFE]]/[[SunGard]] Financial Engineer of the Year in 2005.

== Work ==
Boyle is best known for initiating the use of [[Monte Carlo method]]s in [[option (finance)|option pricing]]. Other well-known contributions in the area of [[quantitative finance]] include the use of the [[Trinomial tree|Trinomial method]] to price [[Option (finance)|options]].<ref>[http://www.global-derivatives.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=15&Itemid=31#Trinomial European Options] on ''global-derivatives.com''. Accessed September 11, 2013.</ref> His seminal work on [[Monte Carlo method|Monte Carlo-based]] [[Option_(finance)#Model_implementation|option pricing]] facilitated the 1980s explosion in the world of derivatives.

== Publications ==
Boyle has authored and co-authored numerous articles.<ref>[http://www.wilmottwiki.com/wiki/index.php/Boyle%2C_Phelim complete list], wilmottwiki</ref> A selection:
* Boyle, Phelim P. "[http://ideas.repec.org/a/eee/jfinec/v4y1977i3p323-338.html Options: A monte carlo approach]." Journal of financial economics 4.3 (1977): 323-338.
* Boyle, Phelim P. "A lattice framework for option pricing with two state variables." Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis 23.1 (1988): 1-12.
* Boyle, Phelim P., Jeremy Evnine, and Stephen Gibbs. "Numerical evaluation of multivariate contingent claims." Review of Financial Studies 2.2 (1989): 241-250.
* Boyle, Phelim P., and [[Ton Vorst]]. "Option replication in discrete time with transaction costs." The Journal of Finance 47.1 (1992): 271-293.
* Boyle, Phelim, Mark Broadie, and Paul Glasserman. "Monte Carlo methods for security pricing." Journal of economic dynamics and control 21.8 (1997): 1267-1321.
